post_info.post_title: Should we have the right to Die?

Matthew S
Yes we should have the right to choose when we diebut the doctor should not be forced legally to follow our wishes. We should find someone who would help us out.

Obvious Child

You can ask them, but they could go to prison if they do.
 
 I don't know where I stand on this. In some cases its good but it seems to happen a LOT where it's legalised, and there's the problem of pressure and less incentive for good nursing homes etc.
 
 Essentially, I think that any euthanasia would become euthanasia on demand, and this would be too easy a get-out and too likely for people to feel under emotional pressure.
snakespit

I don't know where I stand on this. In some cases its good but it seems to happen a LOT where it's legalised, and there's the problem of pressure and less incentive for good nursing homes etc.

 What is a good nursing home? Take it from someone who has hauled these poor, abused elderly people out of these disease farms so called nursing homes. I would guess that as a paramedic I have been to probably about 50 nursing homes in my career, and I would not put my mother in 49 of them. I would sooner put my mother in prison where it is at least somewhat clean, and people actually keep an eye on you. 
 
 
Essentially, I think that any euthanasia would become euthanasia on demand, and this would be too easy a get-out and too likely for people to feel under emotional pressure.

 So what? If that is what you want...? Make it like buying a handgun, a 3 day waiting period.

And speaking of the second amendment, it's not hard to kill yourself. It's pretty hard for the government to stop you from killing yourself. They have a hard enough time preventing unwanted murder. The right to life extends to the right to have control over your own life, including ending it if wanted.

it should not be legal to kill yourslef, if you really want to kill yourself you will do it anyways (what do you have to loose once your gone, besides life?). So why should the doctors kill people when people can do it themselves?

 The Oregon legislation concerns people with degenerative diseases who are suffering to an extent that their quality of life is unacceptable. It involves repeated consultations with MDs and a period of time for reflection on the decision. In most cases they don't have the physical ability to take their own life.

(or better said *Alive*)" - they hear something on the State-news, they'll read a Book by ph.d'ed nuts (with death-agendas) but don't even know, that "science" to this day, has NOT got a workable map/answer. People's perceptions are mostly the result of mass-deception.
 
 Today's general-public is so brain-washed by the worst of "science", that people don't even know anymore that "Murder is wrong". And they'll argue for years on Boards like this one here, about it.

 umm, what does murder being wrong have to do with science? Or as you say it, "science"?
H. Faction

It is a dismally common argument on the part of religionists to claim that "science has/hasn't PROVEN where life begins/ends."
 
 The fact is that this is not a scientific question, it is a philosophical one. Any time a person claims scientific authority in establishing or disproving a certain threshold of life/non-lifie, you can bet that they are covering for a weak philosophical basis of their definitions of life/non-life.
 
 Any valid argument which can be the basis of social policy must adress a set of necessary and sufficient conditions for the status of "human life".
 
 According to widely accepted legal and social practice in the US:
 
 We know that an inanimate object or microorganism has no rights.
 
 We generally accept that non-human animals and plants have the right to be properly husbanded, but do not have a right to life in the sense that humans do (both are killed in vast numbers for food, or to make way for development, or as pests).
 
 We do not assert that human tissue, such as a blood sample, has a right to life, even though it is a] metabolically alive, and b] genetically human.
 
 Given these practices:
 
 When does the lack of nervous activity make a human body more like a turnip than a person?
 
 Why should a very small clone (grown from donor tissue) be more like a baby than like a blood sample?
 
 The right to life of a neurologically active, aware, and informed humans being having been stipulated, who'se will actualises this right? The person's or the state's?
 
 etc.
 
 
 I do not propose to answer these questions, nor to define for you what the necessary and sufficint conditions for each class of being should be. I further do not propose to limit what rights may in analysis be assigned to which class of beings.
 
 I simply demand that people do away with appeals to "science" to "empirically determine" distinctions between classes which the questioner has not sufficienly defined.

I'm guessing it was a reference to "Dr. Death", Dr. Jack Kevorkian. This morbid freak used to take pictures of dying people's eyes because he believed that you could see the life pass from them that way. 
 http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/americas/222218.stm

 
 
 ok now that's disgusting. If they want to die, fine help them do it. But to go on a campaign going around doing assisted suicides???
Caprii

Death. A very mysterious thing wouldn't you say?
 
 Nature brought us and nature will take'th away. emoticon_wow 
 
 Do we have the right to kill ourselves? Well, one thing is certain, even if you didn't have the right and did it anyway, no one will prosecute you or throw your corpse in jail now will they.
 
 Aren't we killing ourselves a slow death by excessive eating, smoking, and/ or drinking alcohol. I guess its the self-inflicted quick death the government doesn't like. 
 
 People wanting to make the great escape before their time is ready, I think need to find help. Nope, not mental help necessarily, but the help that will fix their current situation, whatever that may be. 
 
 If its pain they want to runaway from, then what kind of pain is it, and do we have the right medication/or therapy to make them painfree. If its financial fear they want to runaway from "riches to rags" syndrome, then we need to re-teach them, that life isn't about money and everything is do-able, even if you're thousands of dollars in debt, life can still be rewarding, family members still rely on you.
 
 If it's emotional pain, we need to get the right support for that individual.
 
 Our fears and pain are real and are a part of us and who we are. Just like everyone is unique, the reason people want to commit suicide are unique to that person's personality, and their coping mechanism.
 
 No one should have the "right" to kill themselves, because I think its faulty thinking that places them in that state of mind. Sometimes, perhaps most of the time, we can't correct their frame of mind, we don't have the knowledge and capability to help them.
 
 I have heard people who are in constant physical pain, that the pain is too much and unbearable, and for them wan't to die, then recently I met a woman, who is very ill (lots of pain) with a terminal illness and is in the hospital every month, and she has the most pleasant words to say everyday, wan't to get out there and do things, and you can tell her life is a struggle for her, but she is always so cheerful. Does she think about suicide? I don't know? I don't know her personally, maybe she does.
 
 If we can't offer relief from severe pain, be that emotional or physical, then I can't fault any individual for suicide. I try to place myself in that person's situation, and if I was in so much pain where I cried everyday, I know I wouldn't want to live.
Tastyfish

The debate here always confuses me more than the actual issue itself, as it seems to always end up with some people demonstrating how they would rather die than suffer the indigity of their current condition which is then countered with some people who are happy with whatever disabilities they have.
 
 I don't see a problem with letting the ones who want to go, go and making the ones who don't just more comfortable or leaving them as they are. Even if legalised it will be the same as most elective procedures and require a couple of sessions with a psychologist or councilor before it can go ahead.
 
 The more interesting issue seems to me, whether or not you are allowed to help someone against their will - clearly we have no problem trying to talk people out of suicides normally or even preventing them if we can. Is the same true for people in apparently terminal conditions? Is it ethical to not give up when the patient does?
zachvac

Death. A very mysterious thing wouldn't you say?
 
 Nature brought us and nature will take'th away. emoticon_wow

 If its pain they want to runaway from, then what kind of pain is it, and do we have the right medication/or therapy to make them painfree. If its financial fear they want to runaway from "riches to rags" syndrome, then we need to re-teach them, that life isn't about money and everything is do-able, even if you're thousands of dollars in debt, life can still be rewarding, family members still rely on you.
 
 If it's emotional pain, we need to get the right support for that individual.
 
 Our fears and pain are real and are a part of us and who we are. Just like everyone is unique, the reason people want to commit suicide are unique to that person's personality, and their coping mechanism.
 
 No one should have the "right" to kill themselves, because I think its faulty thinking that places them in that state of mind. Sometimes, perhaps most of the time, we can't correct their frame of mind, we don't have the knowledge and capability to help them.
 
 I have heard people who are in constant physical pain, that the pain is too much and unbearable, and for them wan't to die, then recently I met a woman, who is very ill (lots of pain) with a terminal illness and is in the hospital every month, and she has the most pleasant words to say everyday, wan't to get out there and do things, and you can tell her life is a struggle for her, but she is always so cheerful. Does she think about suicide? I don't know? I don't know her personally, maybe she does.
 
 If we can't offer relief from severe pain, be that emotional or physical, then I can't fault any individual for suicide. I try to place myself in that person's situation, and if I was in so much pain where I cried everyday, I know I wouldn't want to live.

 
 Or maybe their life is just hard and they'd rather go to their version of heaven. It's nice that you know for a fact that their decision makes them insane. I'm sure people with different religions also have some sort of mental problem. Sure there are some who either have some sort of real mental disorder/disease and just blow something out of proportion. But as an example there was another thread on this forum about a girl who had parents who punished her because she ONLY got a 96%. If she didn't win a state piano competition, she would have been punished. She was punished by being forced to stand naked in a corner and was pretty much forced to study all the time. She chose to murder her parents, but I could see committing suicide there.
 
 I tried putting myself in her shoes. First I'd call 911/child abuse or whatever it is if I could find a number. But what if they decide it isn't child abuse or your parents just lie? Then they treat you even worse for trying to turn them in. Your life is a living hell. I'm telling you I would probably either follow her path or kill myself.
Caprii

I never said people are insane because they may want to commit suicide or even kill for that matter. It has nothing to do with insanity but perception. Most humans are "normal" in the mental capacity, but we all have our own little quirks, but most of us our "normal" unless one is diagnosed with a mental retardation or mental disorder, pretty much we all are "mentally the same". Even someone who kills is not necessarily insane, they are very "normal". 
 
 Anger is a reason (not the only reason) why people commit violence and even murder. Because we get angry, doesn't mean we are "insane", when some people get angry, they calm down and do nothing, others might be violent towards another, and others will kill another because they are angry, and at no point does "insanity" come into the picture, but moreso, one's perception is the key reason why people react the way they do. 
 
 Even people with depression or physical pain where they want to commit suicide, does not mean they are insane, farthest from the truth. When I say faulty thinking, its more like not having the knowledge or resources to lift them out of their situation. For example, when we had the great drepression in America, and men were jumping out of the windows committing suicide because of financial loss, they didn't go insane, but they "viewed" money more important than life itself, their perception/way of thinking is faulty because they may felt like they dug a hole to big to get out and not knowing how to get out, they commit suicide. When we all know if someone can teach us methods of coping then almost everything can be dealt with.
 
 As for the girl in your example zach. I couldn't tell you what was in her mind. Was she ever insane? No.
 
 Every person is different when they internalize pain. Years of emotional abuse and other abuse, she filtered it the only way she knew how, being from parent who were from China ( I believe), this girl may have perceived a cultural obstacle as well, who knows its all speculation, only she knows her true intentions. Even so, at no point do I think this child was ever insane, and quite opposite she is very brilliant, but COPING, its all about coping, and if no one is showing her how to cope with her anger, and she has to find the answers herself, then her way of thinking is faulty when she commits murder (not insane). At no point was this girl crazy, no one was there to show her how to cope and redirect her anger.

Like the whole set-up about "Organ-transplating".

 Set-up about organ transplanting? What "set-up" are you referring to?
 
 
Most in the general-public have NO-clue what goes on in ICU (neuro, or otherwise). Like the threads here about "when is a brain dead? (or better said *Alive*)" - they hear something on the State-news, they'll read a Book by ph.d'ed nuts (with death-agendas) but don't even know, that "science" to this day, has NOT got a workable map/answer.  Ummmm....we have standardized tests that we can use to examine brain function and structure to determine brain death. Have you ever heard of an EEG? Apnea test? PET scanning? CT scanning? MRI? Cerebral angiography? Transcranial doppler sonography? Somatosensory and brain stem auditory evoked potentials testing? Technetium Tc 99mm brain scan? Corneal reflex testing? Oculo-cephalic reflex testing? Vestibulo-ocular reflex testing? Upper and lower airways stimulation testing? 
 
 No "science" indeed. emoticon_rolleyes 
 
 I do have a clue what goes on in the ICU. Perhaps you should learn a little "science" yourself, before you go talking about things you don't understand. 
 
 
Today's general-public is so brain-washed by the worst of "science", that people don't even know anymore that "Murder is wrong". And they'll argue for years on Boards like this one here, about it.

 This thread is about suicide, not murder. How could it be murder if I ask a doctor to assist in my suicide?
BeTolerant

Should we or should we not. It's an ethical question and one not easy to answer. Religious belief says you must not kill, and therefore killing a person whether he's healthy and happy, or living in permanent agony from terminal disease, is a crime against GOD. The profound belief to preserve life, has made difficult to legislate Euthanasia. The only country (which I know of) in the world where it's legal for doctors to perform euthanasia, is The Netherlands. Doctors can choose to turn off the the machine which keeps a terminally ill patient alive. They can choose not to give a suffering patient his medicine, etc. However there has been some controvercy, because questions have been asked whether or not some patients where in fact terminally ill or not. It has come to attention that some doctors "abuse" this right, and choose not to treat patients as they see fit. Personally I think it should be illegal, mainly because of the dilemma as to when it should be used and when it should not.
